9 Speaking Rules To Command Any Room
(and be heard, respected, and remembered)

The leaders we admire most,
Craft their words with surgical precision.

Their influence isn't natural.
They follow specific rules that most people don't know.

Here's your playbook to become an unforgettable speaker:

1. The "Three Levels Up" Rule
â†³ Filter every detail through this lens:
"Does it matter three levels up?"
â†³ If not, save it for the documentation
â†³ Keep your message strategically focused

2. The "Silence Sandwich" Strategy
â†³ Pause 3 seconds before & after your key message
â†³ Watch attention spike, memory deepen
â†³ Simple technique, executive impact

3. The "30-70 Rule"
â†³ 30% data, 70% strategic narrative
â†³ Turn information into inspiration
â†³ Keep your audience invested, not overwhelmed

4. The "Elevator First" Framework
â†³ Distill your message to 30 words
â†³ Lead with it, even in hour-long presentations
â†³ Everything else supports this core message

5. "Active Engagement"
â†³ Read the room every 5 minutes
â†³ Engagement dropping? Pivot to discussion
â†³ Keep control through connection

6. "Message Echo"
â†³ Circle back to your core message every 10 minutes
â†³ Reinforce your strategic thread
â†³ Build lasting impact

7. "What-So What-Now What"
â†³ Present the insight
â†³ Share the strategic importance
â†³ Drive clear action

8. The "High-Stakes Opener"
â†³ Start with your most powerful insight
â†³ Lead with what matters most
â†³ Everything else amplifies your opening

9. The "Clarity Check"
â†³ If you can't say it in one breath, simplify
â†³ Sharp thinking creates sharp speaking
â†³ Impact comes from clarity

Your words either add weight or waste time.
Choose wisely.

Whoâ€™s the best speaker youâ€™ve seen - and why?

 Followfor impactful leadership insights.

For post 22 in the series, Iâ€™d love to hear some stories on how your company or organization is witnessing the impact of potential 
#tariffs from Mexico or Canada.

The magnitude of the sheer potential of 25% tariffs of Mexico has already caused a massive restructure in an outdoor company Iâ€™m very familiar with, as their product was made in Mexico, they couldnâ€™t pass a tariff that size onto their customers- since the purchase orders were written months before the tariffs were announced- and effectively every piece of product brought in would be sold with no profit margin. I doubt they are the only company experiencing this.

Itâ€™s another story for product thatâ€™s ordered consistently, where prices can fluctuate and suppliers can simply raise prices. Doesnâ€™t mean that price will stick, unless there are limited alternatives. Think
. Mexico represents 40+% of the international market. Here are some other categories:

comments.commentText:
Right now, what I can share is my perspective on how tariffs might affect the retail shoe market, particularly independent comfort footwear stores.

For SKUs manufactured in Mexico or China, I believe a 25% tariff will translate directly into higher retail prices. Based on my calculationsâ€”factoring in ex-factory cost, load (tariff and transportation), wholesale margin, and retailer marginâ€”a shoe that was previously selling for around $90 at retail will now likely be priced at $115 or more.

We can do similar illustations on higher priced footwear, for Canada.

Beyond the immediate price increase, both wholesalers and retailers may consider taking a higher margin as a precautionary measure. The concern is that this initial 25% tariff could escalate further due to the ongoing political and diplomatic strategies that may lead to tit-for-tat tariff adjustments. in those tariffs. If that happens, businesses may need to adjust margins further to maintain profitability and manage uncertainty. Unfortunately, some consumer sales will decline if prices become too high.

8 Reasons Youâ€™re Not Behind in Life 

(And How to Stop Thinking You Are)

Do you ever feel like you're behind where you "should" be in life? You're not alone. It's easy to fall into the comparison trap, judging your progress against others.

But the truth is, you're not behind at all.

Here are 8 reasons why:

1/ Your timeline is unique to you
â†³ Comparing your progress to othersâ€™ is a recipe for frustration.
â†³ Everyone moves at their own pace - trust your journey.

2/ Growth isnâ€™t always visible
â†³ Some growth happens behind the scenes.
â†³ Youâ€™re always evolving, even when itâ€™s not obvious to others.

3/ Life doesnâ€™t follow a set path
â†³ Success isnâ€™t linear - there are many roads to the same destination.
â†³ Flexibility and adaptation are key to thriving, not following someone elseâ€™s rules.

4/ Youâ€™ve already made progress
â†³ Itâ€™s easy to forget how far youâ€™ve come when you focus on where you want to be.
â†³ Take time to celebrate how much youâ€™ve achieved so far.

5/ Failures donâ€™t define you
â†³ Setbacks are lessons, not roadblocks.
â†³ Each failure brings you closer to success - embrace them as growth opportunities.

6/ Time is relative
â†³ You donâ€™t have to have everything figured out by a certain age.
â†³ Life is a marathon, not a sprint - take it at your own pace.

7/ Thereâ€™s no "perfect" time
â†³ Waiting for the "perfect" moment to start something can keep you stuck.

8/ Youâ€™re where you need to be

The only person you should compare yourself to is you. How have you grown? What are you proud of? Progress takes patience, persistence and self-compassion. You've got this.

postsData.content:
From winning leadership awards early to learning what leadership actually means decades later...

From elementary school through university, I collected leadership awards.

Back then, I thought being a leader was about being decisive and loudâ€“ charting a path, making decisions, and telling people what to do.

Looking back now, I sometimes cringe thinking about it... I was not a leader â€“ I was just a loud kid who refused to follow directions I didn't agree with.

Fast forward to today, after years of researching and working with industry experts and work-culture leaders, my perspective has completely transformed.

Leadership isn't about standing out or charging ahead. It's not about being the loudest or most commanding voice in the room.

It isn't about you at all.

True leadership is about empowering others to thrive.

It's about listeningâ€”really listeningâ€”and creating the space for others to grow, collaborate, and succeed.

The data backs this up:

86% of employees who received meaningful feedback in the last week are fully engagedâ€”compared to just 23% of workers overall. Active listening itself can increase collaboration and productivity by up to 25%.

Even more telling: 80% of workplace conflicts stem from poor communication. But when leaders focus on active listening, employee satisfaction jumps by 30%.

Over the years, I've learned three things little Jean didn't appreciate that actually transform bosses into inspiring and impactful leaders:

 Listen first, ask second.
Leadership isn't about having all the answersâ€”it's about understanding the questions. Active listening helps leaders uncover what their team truly needs to thrive.

 Empower, don't control.
A leader's role is to bring out the best in others. This means assigning roles based on strengths, providing the resources to set them up for success, and trusting your people to do great work.

 Model collaboration.
Great leaders show their teams how to work together by practicing collaboration themselvesâ€”valuing diverse perspectives and making space for every voice at the table.

At Octopy, we bring this philosophy to life through human-focused leadership workshops, keynote speaking, and custom programming.

What's one lesson that's transformed your understanding of leadership?

Let's talk about it in the commentsâ€”I'd love to hear your thoughts.

"It can't be that simple."

Well, yes. Actually it can...

See waaay back when I started as a product marketer in b2b tech, I had a problem.

â†’ As a product marketer, you're the expert in the product...
â†’ AND you're the the expert in the audience.
â†’ Because your job is to connect the two.

You'd think a product marketer in b2b tech -- ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜¥ğ˜¦ğ˜§ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¦ğ˜¥ ğ˜¦ğ˜¹ğ˜±ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜µ ğ˜ªğ˜¯ ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜±ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜¥ğ˜¶ğ˜¤ğ˜µ -- would have to be technical.

How else could you become the expert in a technical product?

But me? I had about as much technical talent as a crayon.

Did that stop me? HELL NO!

I leaned in on what I knew from back in my college days.

Ancient Greek Philosophy.

Aristole defined the ESSENCE of something as "the what it was to be."

I figured if I could get to the essence of the product, starting with the deepest level features and working my way up, then I could understand the product at its core.

I could get to its essence.

That's when I came up with the three big rock questions at the center of everything I do today, working with founders and marketers to create their own killer messaging that attracts more of the right buyers.

What I've learned after practicing this technique for more than 20 years is this:

When you get to the essence of something, somethign cool happens.

â†’ Explaining it
â†’ Drawing analogies to it
â†’ Creating content about it

...all becomes second nature.

Because you understand it at its essence, you have the building blocks to create messaging that hits the mark no matter the audience, no matter the situation.

I dove into all this a bit on the first episode of the newpodcast with my main man,.

Here's a peek.

Listen to to entire episode TOMORROW (!!) wherever you dig podcasts.

The secret to great marketing is simple:

Guess and test.

Every successful campaign starts as a shot in the dark.

I learned this over five years of hard knocks.

Your first ad won't work.

Your first copy won't convert.

Your first offer won't sell.

But each test teaches you something new:

â€¢ Which headlines grab attention
â€¢ Which offers people want
â€¢ Which audiences buy

Testing gives you clear data on what works.

Thatâ€™s why the brands that win aren't those with the biggest budgets.

They're the fastest at finding what works.

So stop planning and start testing.

Launch that "bad" landing page.

Run that "weak" ad.

Send that "rough" email copy.

Double down on your winners and cut your losers fast.

That's the whole game.

Test more = Win more

7 Brutal truths youâ€™re trapped in golden handcuffs:

(Most donâ€™t realize until itâ€™s too late.)

â†’ The salary is great.
â†’ The benefits are solid.
â†’ The lifestyle is comfortable.

So why does it feel like a trap?

Because security can be deceiving.

What looks like stability might be stagnation.

Hereâ€™s how to know if youâ€™re stuck:

1ï¸âƒ£ You dread Mondays but stay for the benefits

â†³ The thought of work makes you anxious.

2ï¸âƒ£ Your skills are stagnating

â†³ You havenâ€™t learned anything new in months.
â†³ But the bonuses make it feel worth it.

3ï¸âƒ£ Youâ€™re overqualified for your role

â†³ You could do your job in your sleep.
â†³ But the pay cheque keeps you from seeking a challenge.

4ï¸âƒ£ Your values donâ€™t align with the company

"You can't dream of building a billion dollar company while crying over $10k"


Recently had an unfiltered chat withCEO of, about sales outsourcing. When I asked him about successful partnerships with outsourced sales teams, he made his point: "successful companies treat their outsourced sales teams exactly like their in-house talent - anything less is setting yourself up for failure."


Key takeaways from our conversation:

- Treat your $10k outsourced sales investment like you would a $10k employee, they're your team, not your vendor
- A CEO mindset means having a Plan B while fully committing to Plan A
- When products don't sell, stop blaming the outsourced team and start questioning your market assumptions


In the full episode, we covered:

- Why companies choose sales outsourcing vs. building in-house teams
- How to evaluate sales outsourcing agencies beyond fancy websites and promises
- The truth about measuring outsourced sales performance and ROI
- Why running market validation with outsourced teams beats rushing to hire in-house
- How to set realistic expectations for your outsourced sales partnerships


Check out the full conversation in the comments

Harnessing the Power of the Halo Effect in Marketing 

The best marketers know this powerful psychology concept: the Halo Effect.


Hereâ€™s the magic:

1. A positive view of one brand aspect.
2. Leads to a positive view of the whole brand.


Picture this in a hotel:

- You walk into a stunning lobby and think, "Wow."
- Naturally, you assume the rooms are equally impressive.


Smart hotels utilize strong visuals to shape guest perceptions.

You can do the same in marketing.
- Skip overloading with details.
- Focus on strong symbols that shape perceptions.


It's not about more messages.


It's about highlighting the right ones.

4 Skills That Helped Me Build Genuine Connections with My Network 


When I started networking, I struggled to make meaningful connections. I used to think networking was just about exchanging business cards or sending connection requests.

But over time, I realized that real connections are built through trust, value, and authenticity.

Here are 4 skills that helped me build strong and genuine relationships:


1. Active Listening

I used to focus more on what to say next rather than truly listening. But when I started paying attention, asking follow-up questions, and showing genuine interest, conversations became deeper and more meaningful.

- Studies show that good listeners are 40% more likely to build strong relationships because people feel valued and heard.


2. Being Helpful Without Expectations

Instead of reaching out only when I needed something, I started offering helpâ€”whether it was sharing a resource, giving feedback, or introducing people to the right connections.

According to research, people who give without expecting immediate returns build stronger long-term networks.


3. Sharing My Experiences Openly

I used to hesitate to share my struggles and lessons, thinking they werenâ€™t valuable. But when I started sharing my journeyâ€”both wins and failuresâ€”I noticed more people resonated with me.

Authenticity creates trust, and trust builds meaningful connections.


4. Emotional Intelligence (EQ)

I worked on understanding peopleâ€™s emotions, responding with empathy, and adapting my communication style.

Research shows that people with high EQ are 3x more successful in building lasting relationships because they make others feel understood and valued.


Remember, Networking isnâ€™t just about numbers; itâ€™s about genuine relationships that grow over time.


Do you agree?

Stav Vaisman
postsData.content:
Your brand truth doesn't change with each generation.

The way you show it does.

I keep seeing brands create entirely different personalities for different age groups.

One voice for Gen Z. Another for Millennials. A third for Gen X.

That's not cross-generational marketing.

That's brand schizophrenia.

The core of your brand - what you stand for - should resonate across generations. It's the manifestation that evolves.

Take sustainability, for example:

- Gen X responds to environmental legacy
- Millennials engage with systemic change
- Gen Z gravitates toward collective action

Same truth. Different expressions.

The strongest brands I've worked with don't shape-shift between generations.

They translate their core message into different cultural languages.

When we focus on translation rather than transformation, our message becomes clearer.

Our impact grows stronger.

Our brand builds true cross-generational resonance.

comments.commentText: Absolutely agree, it's crucial to stay true to the brand's core values across generations.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! A unified brand truth, expressed in relatable ways, fosters deeper connections across generations. Its about resonance, not rhetoric!

Artificial Intelligence Investors Group: Robotics, Machine Learning, NLP, Computer Vision & IoT
Artificial Intelligence Investors Group: Robotics, Machine Learning, NLP, Computer Vision & IoT
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 4 â€“ Update Agent LEARNING
 Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (all links in my comment below)

A report in Quanta magazine provides an example: The idea of a â€œbankâ€ has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. â€œItâ€™s more abstract, really different from what youâ€™re seeing,â€ said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3 of this series.

In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not â€œknowâ€ anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights! The contrast between human learning and LLM processes truly highlights the potential of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem. Excited for Part 5!
